qas.question: Who argues that the word *slava once had the meaning of worshipper?
Who speculates that *slava derives from a reconstructed Proto-Indo-European *(s)lawos?

answers.text: a man from a certain place

qas.question: Who argued that the Old East Slavic Slavuta for the Dnieper River was derived from slova?
Who said slava evolved from an ethnonym?
What was the name of the scholar that suggested Slova could be a river name?
When did Bartek argue the Dnieper River was the origin of Slovene?
What suffix indicates a river name?

context: Alternative proposals for the etymology of *Slověninъ propounded by some scholars have much less support. <a0_0><b4_0>Lozinski<b4_0/><a0_0/> argues that the word *slava once had the meaning of worshipper, in this context meaning "practicer of a common Slavic religion," and from that evolved into an ethnonym. <a1_0><b5_0>S.B. Bernstein<b5_0/><a1_0/> speculates that it derives from a reconstructed Proto-Indo-European *(s)lawos, cognate to Ancient Greek λαός laós "population, people," which itself has no commonly accepted etymology. Meanwhile, others have pointed out that the suffix <b8_0>-enin<b8_0/> indicates <a2_0>a man from a certain place<a2_0/>, which in this case should be a place called Slova or Slava, possibly a river name. The Old East Slavic Slavuta for the Dnieper River was argued by <a3_0>Henrich Bartek<a3_0/> (<b6_0>1907<b6_0/>–<b7_0>1986<b7_0/>) to be derived from slova and also the origin of Slovene.
